FacilityName: South Coles Levee Gas Plant - Central Resources

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The South Coles Levee Gas Plant was built in the 1940's.  Since 1993, the facility has been owned and operated by CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC.

CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. maintains a commitment to worker and public safety as evidenced by the resources invested in accident prevention and in the consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the plant.  

CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. maintains a code of safe work practices under the umbrella of the Illness and Injury Prevention Program (IIPP).

The process plant is regulated under Cal OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 California Code of Regulations Section 5189. 

The CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. PSM Program has fourteen elements paralleling the regulatory structure.  CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. has in place programs, policies and procedures to address each of these elements.  A brief summary of the CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. PSM program is presented below.

Employee Participation: CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. employees receive PSM training, are involved in Process Hazard Analyses, and participate in the Management of Change Process.

Process Safety Information: CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. maintains plant mechanical and process information under the specification of the PSM program.  

Process Hazard Analysis: CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC has completed the PHA for 2013.

 Operating Procedures:  CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. employees participate in a computer-based training system designed for operating procedures.

Training:  CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. incorporates a combination of classroom and computer based training for PSM purposes.

Contractors:  CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. requires companies providing contractual services to provide PSM trained and qualified personnel.  CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. personnel review contractor safety and training programs.   In addition, all contractor employees and visitors working in or near the process areas are required to attend video based site-specific hazard awareness tra

ining.

Pre-Job Start-Up Review: As part of the Management of Change process CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. will not allow new or modified equipment to be started up without the completion of Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) form. 

Mechanical Integrity (MI): CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. has in place a comprehensive MI program that provides guidelines and requirements for preventative maintenance and inspection of critical process equipment. The mechanical Integrity part of the prevention program includes ultrasonic testing of process lines and vessels.

Hot Work Permit: CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. utilizes a Hot Work Permit system to control the use of fire or spark producing activity in process areas.

Management of Change (MOC): CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. has in place a MOC policy that governs any change that may affect process safety.  CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. personnel are trained in MOC procedures and are involved in MOC execution.  The 2008 MOC has been reviewed to ensure adequate hazard review, and action item closure. The cumulative body of changes has not altered the basic risk of the process.

Incident Investigation: CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. has a policy for prompt and effective investigation of all workplace injuries, incidents or near misses.  

Emergency Planning and Response: CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. maintains an emergency response plan in compliance with local emergency response agencies dated August 30, 2013.  Tabletop drills are conducted in training sessions attended by all CENTRAL RESOURCES, INC. employees at the facility.

Accidental Release: In the event of an accidental release, the facility operators are trained to sound the alarm, contact 9-1-1, shut off the source from a safe location or activate one of the emergency shutdown devices, and secure the area.   The 9-1-1 system is used to notify the Fire Department.

Based on the criteria of 40 CFR 68.10 and 19 CCR 2735.4, this facility has not had an accidental release in the last 5 years.  This information was ver

ified by the reviewing records from the Certified Unified Program Agency.

The worst-case release scenario of 389,645 pounds of liquefied petroleum gasoline liquids is based on the Environmental Protection Agency model.  The scenario indicates a 1-psi overpressure distance of 0.6 miles.  This distance does not impact public receptors. 

Compliance Audits: Compliance audits are conducted at three year intervals. The last was completed October 2011.

The plant is functionally divided into three sections: Gas Plant, Compression Storage, and Refrigeration Skid.  The main function of the facility is to extract liquid hydrocarbons and prepare produced gas for sales.  The natural gasoline liquids are stored in multiple pressure vessels, the largest being 80,000 gallons.  

This is a remote facility.

All visitors entering the property must undergo a site safety orientation and check in prior to each visit.  

Seismic parameters were addressed by conducting a walkthrough of the facility and reviewing the mechanical integrity records.  There were no significant indications of deterioration. 



The seismic walkthrough was conducted as a requirement of the California Accidental Release Prevention Program, 19 CCR 2735.  During the preliminary visits, it was believed that this facility would fall under a RMP/CalARP Program Level 3 due to the process safety management regulatory oversight.  However, after consideration of the remote location and discussions with the Certified Unified Program Agency, (Dale Hineman and Dan Starky, April 19, 1999), the South Coles Levee Unit qualified as a Program Level 1.  External events analyses are not required for Program Level 1 filing.  



The seismic walkthrough consisted of a visual inspection the process area piping and vessels above grade.  Structural integrity below grade was not conducted.  Attached are the parameters used during the walkthrough and a plot map indicating the areas of the facility were visually inspected.  



In gener

al, the physical condition of the facility is consistent with the original construction and subsequent modifications were built to design standards for the year of modification.  There were no significant findings.  Based on the document ?Maps of Known Active Fault Near-Source Zones in California and Adjacent Portions of Nevada:  Uniform Building Code 1997, this facility does not reside within the boundaries of a Type A or Type B near Source Fault Zone.





South Coles Levee Gas Plant - Central Resources, Inc.

RMP Submittal

Executive Summary

Oct 2013
